raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "When the acute phase, IgM and IgG antibodies produced against the antigen patient mainly second phase", "confidence": 8, "reasoning": "Q fever is caused by Coxiella burnetii, which undergoes phase variation. Phase I organisms have complete LPS with O-antigen (virulent, found in nature and acute infection). Phase II organisms lack O-antigen sugars (avirulent, occurs after laboratory passage). During acute Q fever infection, antibodies are primarily directed against Phase II antigens, while chronic infection shows antibodies against Phase I antigens. The student's answer (option 2) is incorrect because both phases can inhibit phagosome-lysosome fusion - this is a general virulence mechanism of C. burnetii, not phase-specific. Option 0 is wrong (phase variation involves LPS changes, not flagella - C. burnetii lacks flagella). Option 1 is backwards (Phase I HAS O-antigen, Phase II lacks it).", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
